characters: COME ON YOU BASTARD LET US IN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy Cobb, early thirties, is digging an English garden i the hot sun. He is lean, naked to the waist. It's hard to tell which century he inhabits. Only when he stops to dri from a plastic bottle do we realise he is of our time.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And love slipped the bonds of restraint... At a table under a willow tree sits Tess - early fifties, funky specs - at a laptop. She pauses in her typing, star at Andy.

dialogues.speaker: TESS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His touch was like a cosmic `yes'. Underneath a converted barn, cross-legged on a bench in a bikini top, sits Eustacia. She is hunched over a note pad writing at tremendous speed, oblivious to all but her wor

dialogues.speaker: EUSTACIA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: `Fuck you,' screamed Kelly, `Fuck you to hell!' Scott stepped back from the cell door as the gob of spit flew.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting at a barn window is American academic Glen McCrea a physically awkward man, more at home with his intellect than his body. He is surrounded by foolscap, post-it note books and markers - dominated by a poster of a dour Victo - Thomas Hardy. He is writing.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This complex contemporary matrix is  what Hardy meant by `the ache of  modernism.'  He regards it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crap. He deletes it. He looks at his blank screen, breathing deeply. The only words left say `Chapter Six'.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Inchcombe had seen it all before. He'd seasoned it: the metallic smell of blood and gunshot; forensics hunched like vultures. The dreadful mundanity of murder, he thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas Hardiment writes fluidly with pencil and paper. good-looking man of fifty. Dark hair, strong figure.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He approached Patel, who was stricken. She was one for whom a corpse was still an obscenity. Inchcombe realised a disturbing truth. His lack of feeling was almost... (He stops writing. Sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathological...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A playground on the edge of an idyllic English village. J Long - fourteen, skinny, restless - is lying at the botto the slide gazing at the clouds. Casey Shaw, her shy, plac best friend, is sitting on a toddler toy, reading aloud f a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `I've been wearing the wrong size all my life,' said Katie. `I was always popping out. Turns out I'm a 30GG,' she says. `Now my bras finally fit - though Simon prefers me without one.' Jody checks to see if her breasts have grown. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman in an upmarket apron is taking a tray of scones a biscuits out of the aga. It's Beth Hardiment. Once pretty she's now mumsy and countrified. She examines her baking, satisfied with its perfection. Mary, the help, is doing the washing-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I should be reminding them to drink enough? It's very hot out there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth - they're writers, not babies. You run round after `em too much. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen walks outside, breathing in the fresh air. Beth approaches with her tray of scones and biscuits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tempt you, Glen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, thanks. Glen picks up a scone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I often take something snacky down to Nicholas at this time of day. I know how the brain needs feeding. How are you settling in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. The last writer's retreat I stayed at kind of froze my balls off, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screeching firedoors, curried lasagne and a needy poet - from whom I still bear the scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We try to keep it peaceful here; far from the madding crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blight on this rural paradise is a vandalised bus she near the only T-junction in the village. A twee shop, han baskets and Grade II listed buildings make up the view. I shatteringly dull. Casey and Jody walk up towards the bus shelter. Their bor is epic. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open-topped BMW goes past and halts briefly by the junction. The tones of Classic FM blare out, much to the enjoyment of the middle aged couple within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frock horrors. This weeks top of the shocks goes to Katie Pound in an off the shoulder lime by Roberto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks like a bug. (Car hoots) Wankers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna sack your stylist girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet they did that on purpose, dressed her up like an insect. Casey agrees. They zoom away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen lowers himself into a comfy garden chair, his mouth of cream and jam. Behind him, Nicholas' shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas is panicking down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Ewedown? Nadia, what the ffff are you doing there? I haven't told her yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadia is walking up the road from the station in her high heels, carrying an overnight bag. She is weeping into her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? You keep saying you want to be with me. Jody and Casey are all ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell her just like that. It's twenty five years; a marriage. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 4A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Nicholas. Or I'm going to get in a taxi and find your farm. Come up there and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drag you out - GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be with you. I thought you'd be pleased...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window Nicholas sees Beth leaving a scone by Diggory, a sleeping poet in a pretentious hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm pleased... Nadia, go to the pub and stay there. I'll come when I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me a couple of hours - He ends the call just as Beth is nearing the door - panic the phone back on to its holder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cock pie. Beth opens the door to see Nicholas apparently hard at it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the worker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good actually. Just about to embark on forensics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well give me your pages and I'll get started. Nicholas hands her several pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckon I might pack it in a bit early today. Need to think about my blood smears. Might take a drive; have a pint. Stir the old grey matter up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who were you talking to just then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy. She says the Impala contracts should be through in a day or two. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 5A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth immediately knows he is lying. The lie pains her. Sh goes to the door. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth decides to try and call his bluff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could come with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a drive. I don't know when we last went out. Buying time by biting his scone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is absolutely yummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go into Hadditon, get a meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but. What about the guests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary's got Casey to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm supposed to be thinking, you know about the -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can run it by me. I'm good at forensics. Nicholas has run out of excuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth approaches Andy with her scones and biscuits. Nearby Glen is sitting back in a sun-lounger. Diggory sleeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tempt you, Andy? Andy takes a scone with a wide smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Glen, our new academic. Turns out he's working on Thomas Hardy. Said he might have some farming questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needs an expert yokel, does he? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 6A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind? And the writers are eating al fresco tonight; could you check there's no bird shit on the seats? Sorry. Beth looks distant, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You OK? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Nicholas and I are going out to dinner. As she walks away, Andy glances at the shed, a look of puzzled dislike on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen settles back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's paradise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas, dreading his predicament, is staring out at a c arse. The cow starts to piss. He shuts his eyes in desperation.

dialogues.speaker: 10A I/E. DAY. TAMARA'S CAR. 10A
dialogues.text: Shooting from inside the car, we pass the sign "Ewedown".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same car drives through the village. Jody and Casey appear from behind a wall and chuck eggs at it. They both land on the windscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking bingo! Jody and Casey run away, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver brakes, swerves and comes to a halt. Tamara Dr gets out. She's twenty eight, startlingly beautiful. She looks around shocked, for the culprit. The immaculate, picturesque street is deserted. Tamara ta it in, with an expression of such distaste that it might well be a landfill site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a dump. As she drives away, we see Nadia sitting outside the pub her urban heels, anxiously smoking a cigarette. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 7A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara drives up to an old farmhouse. She gets out of the and stands at the gate. Air of neglect; dark windows. Tam looks at the place as if it stirs memories. She doesn't m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back of the house Tamara walks through an overgrow neglected garden. She peers through the back door into th kitchen. A thin layer of dust on the surfaces; a sense of recent abandonment. Suddenly a pigeon flies out from the porch eaves - just o her head. Tamara startles. It completely spooks her. She backs away. She doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody and Casey are slouched on the bench at the bus stop. Three teenage boys are doing wheelies over the T-junction One of them almost lands in the shop. An old lady comes o shoo-ing them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could walk up the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be helping my mum up at Stonefield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep you busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never stop, you! Neither of them moves. The boys are yelling. Two try to p the third head first into the bin outside the shop. Jody Casey are not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The writers are sitting round a table lit with tea-lights jars. Casey is helping her mum, Mary, an efficient local woman in her late thirties. She wobbles the heavy serving dishes dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was called `From Hearth to Heath - Doomsday and Revelation in Victorian verse.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh you know. Pale poets on  laudanum, dark towers and sunless  seas - a little sturm and drang in  a teacup.  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an upstairs window we can see Beth hold a dress up to herself and then abandon the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it sell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well my kind of books aren't about sales. I mean that's not why I write. So... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you working on next? Upstairs, through a window, we see Beth is putting on a blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is looking at herself in a cheval mirror. She's full hope that Nicholas will take her out - and dread that he' find some excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Hardy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything left to say about that maudlin bore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me but there is nothing dull about Hardy. That is a misconception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you've been published. I'm seething with envy; I'd love to be published.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I publish myself on the internet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, do you earn money doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lesbian crime. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 9A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey drops a potato in Glen's wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here picking up tips from the master. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the garden is open, letting in the eveing air Nicholas is waiting for Beth by the mirror. He is full of unease - but can't help finding himself handsome. His pho bleeps; a text. He reads it anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, why don't I just pop out on my own? Beth, determined to force things, comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm ready. Come on. She's on her way to join him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that - I mean - are you wearing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just looks a bit... hot. Now Beth knows she is right. She takes her jacket off, gutted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Haddition's always packed with pissed Londonites on a Friday. I doubt we'll get a table anyway. Let's do it properly next week; make an occasion. I'm always taking you for granted. I'm vile I know; you should kick me really, but - He's about to leave. Beth speaks calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is she? The question hangs in the air. Nicholas' smile is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? For a moment, he tries to find a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. Who? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's nothing. It's been once or twice, that's all. Beth, it's not anything. Beth is raw with pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her voice raised) Who is she?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tess faintly hears. She stops mid chew, listening for mor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas coughs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a researcher with Radio 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nadia, Nadia Patel. This hits a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patel? She's in your book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no I met her when I was on Desert Island Discs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put her in your book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Desert Island Discs was a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once or twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to tell you but - Beth utters an inchoate cry. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 11A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tess hears it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh!... Beth's pained voice drifts out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You lying PIG! A hush falls over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, I'm a ruin, I know - but I've been in a real state about this... I didn't want to hurt you. Another wounded cry from Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, Andy picks up his plate and goes. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is incandescent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you lie to my face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk calmly about this? There are people out there -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look me in the face and LIE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake; we're surrounded by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You BASTARD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thrilled intake of breath goes round the table. The wri (with the exception of Glen, who is mortified) are poised like scavengers, waiting for more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, we're like a pair of compasses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you dare -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joined solidly at the top but with the ends able to roam, in freedom - His phone beeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's from her isn't it? Are you keeping her waiting? Nicholas finally snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've talked a lot about the  creative mind and we agreed that it  needs freedom to explore!  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 12A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving the house) Take your freedom. I can't live like this any more. It makes me feel WORTHLESS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey gawps, fascinated. Nicholas is following Beth outside. Her agony travels thr the quiet evening air. The writers are open-mouthed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself down!

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Go set up home with Patel. See if she does your tax return.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Will you please -

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you love her?? Diggory's fork stays in mid-air. Glen is horribly fascina GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is pointless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: YES
dialogues.text: The guests are hanging on every word. Beth retreats back the house.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: If you leave here tonight to be with her... Don't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth... For a moment, she hopes he'll apologise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making fools of us both. Beth, tears stinging, picks a plant out of the tub by the door and hurls it, roots and all. It's a direct hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar. Glen cringes. Beth slams the door. Nicholas wipes soil off his glasses; brushes it off his shirt. He realises with a sinking heart that he must pass writers to get to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know they provided material too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth, her back to the door, is regretting her gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth does everything for him you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: types his manuscripts, deals with  his agent, makes his female  characters convincing.  Nicholas still at the door, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She even came up with the name Dr  Inchcombe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder he's bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope she takes him to the fucking  cleaners.  Nicholas walks to his car. Silence. He roars away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth comes into the kitchen. Her eyes flicker over pictur of her daughter and Nicholas. She is in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day, this is why  I'm glad to be single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is going through agonies of self-criticism.

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nadia Patel. Gazelle eyes. Tantric sex. We see her thoughts: An exotic clinch. Nicholas in thrall Nadia's confident passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would he choose me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gossip flutters round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will she take him back, that's the  question.  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 13B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be torn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's far too up himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the farm though?  Splitting up all this? Must be  worth a fortune. I think she's  very rash, making him choose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, Beth weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas is walking Nadia to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you weren't going to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was busy. Rowing with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your farm? A look of frustration crosses his face. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could have gone on just as we were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said you wanted to be with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. In London. Now and then. Nadia looks at him. The scales are beginning to fall. The get in the car. As they drive away, Tamara's car pulls up She gets out of the car and takes in the pub before enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara enters. Zoe, a buxom Australian, is behind the bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big glass of rioja please. And I need a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, how many nights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know. Just one. Zoe pours the wine. She's disarmingly friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You here on business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Business of a kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to pry; I'm just really nosey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from here. Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice place. Tamara smiles her disagreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep meaning to leave but... Hard to get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mum's house is just up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not staying with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's. She died. Zoe finishes pouring the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have that on me. And here's your key. Up the stairs, right in front. You can't miss it. Tamara utters her thanks, surprised at Zoe's kindness. Sh takes her drink and the key upstairs. Zoe remains, grinni We see why. Andy Cobb has just walked in. Zoe pulls him a pint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't think I'd see you tonight. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit of an atmosphere at Stonefield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me everything...  Andy shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marriage. Remind me never to try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, you're just a sex object. No one'd have you. He grins back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara is in a deep bubble bath. She glances at herself i the mirror, scrutinising her beauty. She fingers her nose Slowly a look of doubt steals over her - as if she's not quite comfortable in her own skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is eating his breakfast looking at all the Hardiment family memorabilia in the kitchen. Andy is eating toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the Hardiments have lived here centuries, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, `bout twenty years. Still strangers by local standards. Beth comes in, tense, anxious and haggard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, come and look at Ingrid. I think she's coming into heat. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a nice lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I owe her a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Husband's a sleazebag, huh?  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd say prick here actually. Or  wanker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. We might even call him  a Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy approaches Beth. She is cleaning out the hen coop wi all the frenetic energy of an abandoned wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going rotten underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we look at Ingrid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do that. Beth... Andy takes the shovel. Beth bites back tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't last five minutes. Beth looks down embarrassed by (but grateful for) his support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen wanders into Beth's office. The wall in front of him dominated by a framed newspaper profile of Nicholas,  surrounded by framed covers of Inchcombe books. The whole room is a shrine to Nicholas' career.  Glen is in the hall looking at Beth's prints and pictures old maps, wildlife and framed letters from grateful write who have stayed at the retreat. He stares at a print of f workers in the nineteenth century. Glen sighs.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know why I'm drawn to Thomas  Hardy. He writes about failure  better than anyone else. I need  this book to go well. I need a tiny  reward for my endeavours...  His stomach gurgles ominously.  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 17A.

dialogues.speaker: GLEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I need a dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen walks down the corridor by the kitchen, to the downstairs cloakroom; a marvellous Victorian toilet of reassuring size. He shuts the door in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is on the loo. Even in this small room there are fra photographs of Nicholas receiving awards. He looks at the wonder.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: If that's the way you feel... Nadia, I'm devastated. Through the frosted window Glen sees Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: But if that's your decision, I'll have to learn to live with it. Beth comes in from the garden. Glen sees Nicholas quickly the call. For Beth's benefit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into his phone) I told you. I love my wife. Don't ever phone me again. Glen is shocked by this duplicity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No don't touch me, don't you dare. Glen panics, realising their reunion is going to be right the door. He puts his hand on the flush, hoping to warn t - too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough. Not any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what you like and then you're sorry? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 18A.

dialogues.speaker: NICHOLAS, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I hate myself. I hate myself. Glen opens the door a chink. They are feet away from him. Nicholas looks unshaven, shagged and guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drove her back to London. Took all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drove her home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was in a state. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she'll get over it?... Nicholas shrugs. To Glen's horror, he starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Then Beth is sobbing too. They are in each other's arms, holding each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm like this. I couldn't do without you. Glen looks away from the clinch, horribly embarrassed. He opens the toilet window, puts the soap dish straight. Loo again - still hugging, sobbing, kissing - puts his hand o the flush - too awful to reveal himself - takes it off ag Straightens his hair, examines his teeth, sweating. He looks again. At last the emotion is abating. Nicholas releases Beth. She wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go to the bottle bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK... Let's talk later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The goat's come into heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Beth goes. Nicholas is watching her; his expression stran He walks away. At last Glen emerges, incredulous at Nicho lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen flops into a sun-lounger near Diggory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just seen the Hardiments kiss and make up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hat is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like she's taking him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the hat is on, it means don't speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Peace is restored. The sound of a burglar alarm suddenly blares over the gar Diggory sits up, infuriated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is following Andy down the hill from Stonefield. The cows are too close for Glen's comfort. He hurries through

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like cows. I mean really. They exude bovine malice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, these girls are killing machines. They don't like Americans either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen and Andy are in the valley between the two farms. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Winnards Farm. Lady there died a while back. Place is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's being robbed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prob'ly just kids. Nothing to do round here except make trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's bad guys? Don't you have a blunderbuss or a fowling piece or something? They climb up through a copse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen and Andy are going up the hill towards Winnards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to belong to my dad, this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it all went tits-up. Land was flogged to a consortium and the house was sold to Londoners; the Drewes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is your ancestral pile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was. Born in that room up there. He points up at the back bedroom window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have been pretty resentful.

dialogues.speaker: 1995. EXT. DAY. WINNARDS FARM
dialogues.text: An eighteen year old Andy jumps off a stile into the lane behind a slim, fifteen year old girl on a horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 21A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl turns. She has a huge nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This farm's mine, big nose. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl kicks the horse into a trot, her nose in the air

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy and Glen turn the corner to the back of the house. Tamara is up a ladder wielding a hammer at the alarm box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what're you doing? Tamara gives the alarm box a great whack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, you moron; it's me. Andy looks more closely. A disturbing spark of recognitio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tam?... Hardly recognise you.  Another whack. The noise becomes a high-pitched squeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't do it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy turns the alarm off. Tamara enters the dusty kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to do bits of work for your mum. Been keeping an eye on the place since she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of work, graphics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do horticulture now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a gardener? Andy says nothing. He stares at her nose. Glen has come i GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a great old house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to buy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really the property-owning kind. Prefer my life to fit into hand  luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you're back, to flog it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a nice second home for some banker wankers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy if you want it, why don't you make me an offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because sadly I'm still prey to the  economic forces that threw the peasant classes off the land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlucky. Tamara opens a cupboard. It's full of empty wine bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tam. Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck have you done to yourself? Tamara's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen and Andy are walking back. Andy is brooding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's completely different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was she before? What's the  story?...  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was nothing. Decade ago. Just a  teenage thing.

dialogues.speaker: 1996. INT. DAY. WINNARDS FARM
dialogues.text: Tamara pulling down her pants; Andy unbuttoning his jeans She jumps up on the worktable, pushing a stack of turnips of the way. They kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should find someone you're in love with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stupid prick. Andy looks at her. She is sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saying you love me, frosty tits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say it; You're the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off. She kisses him. As they start to make love:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Fuck off. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen looks over at Andy, interrupting his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romeo and Juliet, huh?  Andy carries on down the hill, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara is watching Andy walk away with Glen. Her eyes fol him curiously - then she firmly turns her back.  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 24A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara rips a bin liner off the roll and shakes it out. She takes a deep breath. She opens the cupboard and begin bin the distressing mountain of empty wine bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is standing at the hedge looking down at the valley Nicholas at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking of the first time we saw this place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made it a wonderful home Beth. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not wonderful enough. She starts to walk away. Nicholas holds her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can't put this behind you, then we're stuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'd better sort myself out then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has to happen? I am sorry - Beth brings her arm up to push him away. Nicholas catches draws her to him. He kisses her insistently. Beth's resistance diminishes. Soon it has gone. We begin to see depth of Beth's physical love for him. At that moment, Glen walks round the corner. He tries to backtrack, mortified by his intrusion on their passion. T late. They part. Nicholas turns away in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just taking the air. Flustered, he knocks into a tub of lobelias. Beth and Nicholas remain. The moment between them is gone. Round t corner, Glen is cringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody and Casey are reading a celebrity magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you do him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gay, you dobbin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? They turn to a big spread on a band called Swipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swipe. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Sergeant... I'd walk through fire to do him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drummer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not just the drummer. He writes the lyrics; it's his band. He's the fucking genius, not Steve Culley or any of these wankers. It's Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. I'd do Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna be her, in that dress with him licking my teapot lids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casey is still carrying this image as she serves a tray o nibbles on the patio. She stands among the writers, watch a fly get caught in one of the vol-au-vents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People talk about the muscularity in  prose. I want a similar muscularity  in my verse. I don't want a poetry  that's flabby or obese - that's why I  adhere to the tightest rhyme schemes:  Diggory picks the vol-au-vent up and without looking, put in his mouth. Casey moves over to Nicholas and Glen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABB ACC DEE D. They give you the  armature, the beating heart, the  nerve ends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So has the muse shone on you, Greg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been pretty distracted. Most recently by those delicious cookie things that Beth brought round this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Of course we call them biscuits here. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 26A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And by the place itself, the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes wish I could get distracted. Ten page a day man, rain or shine. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that's scary. Ten pages; how  do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Greg -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't presume to give an academic tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact I read one of your books. Another distraction but I thought it was decent stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. He's offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I do it? I just get on with it, Greg. Nicholas walks away leaving Glen smarting. The female wri surround Nicholas. He tops them up, full of charm. Under breath, Glen impersonates:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `We call them biscuits, here.' Nicholas raises his glass for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the muse, however you find her. He is looking at Beth. She is gratified. Then his eye shi his glass still in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that? Tamara Drewe is climbing the stile at the bottom of the garden in a low cut T-shirt, tiny pair of denim shorts an bare feet. The evening light bathes her in a golden sheen GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Tamara Drewe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met her with Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God. What's happened to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had a nose job, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's completely different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Andy said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Tamara. Such a sad girl. She used to come and help you wash the car, didn't she Nicholas? I think she liked a bit of family after her dad left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Tamara Drewe who writes the column in one of the Sundays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to. Writes for the Independent now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spent weeks going on about her nose job. Smart way to pay for it I suppose. Was her old one an awful conk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's poured herself into those shorts. I hope they don't give her thrush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the etiquette with nose jobs? Do we mention it, or... Tamara has arrived in earshot. Absolutely everyone, inclu a very curious Casey, is staring at her nose. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 28A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Sorry to intrude. Her hand defensively brushes her nose. Poppy walks toward her, full of warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poppy, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love your new hooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. It isn't actually new; just smaller... GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last Beth remembers her manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara, so sorry about your mum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you staying down for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to. There's so much to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must let us know if we can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I was going to ask if you could spare a pair of strong arms. I've got a skip coming tomorrow and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas? - Nicholas is opening another bottle of prosecco. It pops i cork over his trousers. He mutters a swear word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm available. I do skips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well thank you. You're very kind... Is Andy around at all? Beth is helping Nicholas wipe his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't spare Andy. He's making a new coop for my Buff Orpingtons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara and Glen are carrying junk out to a skip. Tamara i big boots and a slightly more practical pair of shorts. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is preparing lunch, talking to Poppy. Nicholas is go through his typed-up manuscript; not really listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had the writers down there  helping her all day. I hope she  realises they're here to work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't believe what a difference  her nose makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I think it's a mistake; taken away all her character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on; she looks ten times better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she knows it. I found those shorts really irritating. Going around with half her bum hanging out. I mean, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To annoy people like you. Might get a pair myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're not desperate, are you? Always something a bit desperate about Tamara Drewe. Beth looks at him puzzled as he works on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara and Glen are having a rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why did you change your face? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 30A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changing my face is the best thing I ever did. And I don't care what  anyone thinks.  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it work for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe; if you did the wrinkles too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're just coming on to me... Tamara laughs. She starts work again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your column, you write about  yourself... Does that come easily?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... But it feels right. My first  novel's definitely going to be autobiographical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first novel? You're going to dash one off just like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ideally, I'd like to make it into  fiction before I'm thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then maybe a swimwear collection, a chat show, a pasta sauce range?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life sure is easy for the beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know before I got the nose job  I had no trouble getting taken  seriously. Maybe, when they removed  that bit of cartilage, they pulled  my brain out by mistake - what do  you think?  Glen smiles, won over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is coming from the bar with a pint for Andy and a ha for himself. He has just been served by Zoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's single, man. Andy looks over at Zoe. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 31A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's not exactly a relationship; we just have an occasional thing. Zoe doesn't want to be tied down and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Zoe! Tamara... You should get in there. Marry the girl. Then you get to live back in your ancestral home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. Not her type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trouble is Andy, you think like a loser. And I know that because I'm the loser that losers turn to for tips. I'm the losers loser. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a pedigree loser. I had a graphics business; went bust. And then with my great business acumen I invested in a polytunnel full of ganja.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. How'd that go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made a tit of myself. Spent about six years stoned out of my box and I'm only just getting it back together. Besides, even if I was the last man in the world, Tamara Drewe wouldn't have me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dumped her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you are a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was twenty. My mates thought I was cradle snatching... And they used to call her Beaky.

dialogues.speaker: 1996. EXT. DAY. OUTSIDE THE PUB. 47
dialogues.text: Tamara in her school uniform, is gutted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaky?... We see her stricken face as she turns away. Then she turn back and hits Andy. His nose streams blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is preparing to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told her the truth... The time might come when she respects that. Andy, as your love guru, I suggest you ask Tamara for a date. But take a shower first, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piss off, Glen. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara is in her shorts and boots, chucking empty bottles old saucepans into the skip, like an Amazon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas is at the hedge, looking down the valley towards Winnards Farm. He is watching Tamara like a hawk - as if can't quite believe what he is seeing.

dialogues.speaker: 1996. EXT. DAY. STONEFIELD
dialogues.text: Nicholas and Tamara are polishing Nicholas' car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys know nothing.  Nicholas looks up at her, smiles indulgently. Tamara stop work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been reading `Inchcombe's  Dose.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bit where Doctor Inchcombe  finds himself having thoughts about  the dead guy's daughter.  Tamara walks around the car, bringing her polishing cloth closer to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You describe her light smattering  of freckles and her striking  profile. So...  She turns her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you base her on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you noticed me?  Nicholas looks at her in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I've noticed you...  GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 33A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits, hoping for a kiss, a hug, anything. She puts o hand - almost touches him. He steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think it's time you went.  Tamara is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making yourself ridiculous.  This really hurts. Tamara takes the bucket of soapy water throws it over the car - and Nicholas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholarse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas is still staring at Tamara, who is jumping on th stuff in the skip. Glen is strolling up the hill from the pub. He follows Nicholas' gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man can dream, huh? Nicholas looks at him affronted - as if he doesn't know w he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara, hot and dirty, runs up the stairs with her roll o bin liners. She opens the door to her mother's bedroom. She is completely unprepared for it. A neat, womanly room covered in photographs of Tamara as a child, teen and you woman. On the dressing table is a lipstick; the lid lying next to it as if it has just been used. Tamara picks it u She sits, suddenly exhausted. For the first time, she loo lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara still looks slightly shaken as she walks up to And He is watching Ingrid meet Darcy, a billy goat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on Ingrid; have some kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty direct isn't he? He's not even bought her a coke. Andy turns. Sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he stinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't mind; it's like Lynx to her. If she's ready she'll stand for him, if not she won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's disturbing human.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refreshing basic. Darcy is up and at it. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you'd have gone back to London by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish. Looks like I'm stuck here for a while. Actually, I've got a proposition for you. Andy glances at the goats; bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should go for a drink sometime, Tam. You know, for old times sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we can reminisce about how I smashed your nose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't smash it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just bled. The memory is between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to do the house up before I sell it. It looks like an eighties timewarp. Would you like the job? He just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Painting it and tidying the garden? Good hourly rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be easy down there, Tam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the memories and stuff. Your mum...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 35A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it that you want someone around? Like when you look up I'd be there too? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, the goats are giving

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK it's bollocks -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very sweet of you Andy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you wouldn't want to fraternise with your gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... is that a yes? Andy doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, goat whisperer - I thought I'd be doing you a favour. I thought you needed the work. It's all over with Ingrid and Darcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had a shit time but she'll still call him. He'll lose her number. He won't ring her back... Andy's face cracks into a smile. He is won over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen types a sentence. He reads it. He deletes. He stares the blank page. It stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  He stands. He paces. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just write, you numbskull. You  moron, you dumb fuck - write!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen is passing Beth's office. She's working through a st of fan mail. She smiles when she sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Thomas Hardy? Glen unburdens himself. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 36A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wasting my sabbatical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been working on this book forever; why can't I finish it? I'm two years past my delivery date and Fantail could ask for their chickenshit advance back. I can't write. I'm fucking constipated. It's a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crikey. He notices the In-Tray. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this all his fan mail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do a couple of sessions a week, to keep on top of it. Pretty good at forging Nick's signature. Glen looks awed - and defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be glad to. If you think it would  help.  Beth suddenly sees Andy out of the window. He's leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Glen. Just need Andy -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barging in on you; What an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth catches up with Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're going into Hadditon - we're really low on chicken feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it tomorrow. I'm on my way down to Winnards. Doing one or two jobs for Tamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got you helping her too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just painting, decorating, sorting the garden. Beth is quite put out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, that sounds like a lot. I need you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can easily do both. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 37A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you're not working for her in the hours that I pay you. Without thinking, she has made Andy feel like a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Beth. I won't rip you off. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks on, leaving Beth feeling very uncomfortable - an somehow slightly bereft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy comes in. He shouts into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tam? Got some colour charts for you to see. He sets out all the colours charts and plans he has been  working on. Tamara appears. She is dressed to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you choose for in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'd have this one. And then  upstairs in the bedroom -

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: She starts gathering her things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what d'you have to do to get a cup of tea round here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea bags. Sugar. Fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off to work. Andy stares. Suddenly Tamara is no longer just a blast fr the past. He sees a future - a future that he wants. He slowly smiles back - but she's already striding away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pounding rock music, slightly distorted by distance. Jody Casey are trying to get in over the boundary fence. A security guard is already running towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our village. Our fucking field.

dialogues.speaker: COME ON YOU BASTARD LET US IN
dialogues.text: Jody is ready for a fight but Casey pulls her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is tending to Ingrid - making sure she's not scared the noise. Ingrid looks as if she couldn't give a damn. O by the barn she sees Glen, unaware that he's being watche breaking out of a mournful walk to groove to the music. S smiles. At the other end of the farm, Nicholas is staring over th hedge with tissue paper ear-plugs. He pretends his arm is rifle, like a little boy. He aims at the cows. He fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swipe are playing; bit like The Libertines in their prime There is one girl in the band, bass guitarist Fran Redfor The drummer, Ben Sergeant, is also vocals. The lead singe Steve Culley, is mixed-race; confident and charismatic. He is getting very up-close and personal with Fran. Ben i getting more and more furious. In the wings, we see Tamara talking to a publicist, tryin make herself heard above the roar of the music. She is pointing at Steve and Fran. The publicist nods. Suddenly Ben leaps up and takes hold of Steve, pulling hi away from Fran. There is a scuffle, Fran trying to separa the boys. Ben takes a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry people. I resign. Swipe is no more. Steve Culley is a cunt. Ben storms off the stage. The audience are in uproar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben! Ben! What's happening? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's seeing Fran. I won't work with that tosser again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve! Don't! Steve is coming into the wings. He punches Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking baby. Ben falls. He virtually lands on Tamara. They both hit th ground. Steve storms off - Fran following, calling his na Ben is dazed. He looks up at Tamara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. I'm Tamara Drewe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be interviewing you - for the Independent. She smiles sweetly, smoothing his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was scheduled for later but maybe now's a better time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody, Casey and the boys are sharing a bottle of cider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should let us in free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too right. They come here, drink our water, use our fields, they leave all their crap in our drains - Tamara's car sweeps past with the roof down. It is closel followed by a bright yellow Porsche. Ben is driving and h boxer dog, Boss, is in the passenger seat. Jody clocks hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben! Ben! She jumps up and down in the road with both arms waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 40A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Ben from Swipe! Ben!! GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jody and Casey scream with delight, chasing the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben skids his Porsche to a halt right next to Tamara's ca He jumps out. Boss follows. Tamara is walking towards the door. The distant festival is still audible. Tamara backs towards the door, with Ben inches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allergic are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To indie drummers? Maybe. Who are your influences, Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone asks that. This your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm selling. D'you want it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want something else. Tamara grins. Jody and Casey arrive at the brow of the hi breathless. They see Ben pin Tamara against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck's she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen her up at Stonefield. She's got a nose made of plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come she gets Ben? I've loved him since March. Just as Ben's about to kiss her, Tamara coolly opens the and draws him into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow... Jody is gutted; feeling the full injustice of her life. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara leads Ben to the kitchen. The hall has been stripp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Maureen Tucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Tamara opens the fridge. Ben is inches away. He still has kissed her and he's just about to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe Tucker, with the Velvets. Five foot nothing. Used to stand up to play. Put the snare drum on its side and hit it with mallets. Mentalist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write all the songs; that's pretty rare for a drummer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you've ever heard about drummers is total shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't spontaneously combust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only sometimes. She goes in to kiss him. But Ben grabs a pair of chopstic from a utensils jar. He starts to play around Tamara, hit the surfaces, the shelves and everything on them; a brill rhythm. He gets closer and closer. Tamara is utterly mesmerised. Ben stops. He still doesn't kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any more questions? Tamara is speechless. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy is walking in the copse up to Tamara's. He spots a couple of wild mushrooms and picks them. In the distance sees Glen bending and stretching. A cow is looking at him over the fence. Glen sees it and startles. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sight makes Andy smile. He carries on towards Winnard Farm in high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy comes up to the house. He sees the yellow Porsche; t a large boxer dog sitting by the front garden. It starts barking at him. Andy calms him right down. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey - who are you, mate - lost, are you? Andy strokes Boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy takes a key from under a flower pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy opens the kitchen door. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tam? You want breakfast? Boss bounds inside and disappears. ANDY WOAH -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy is puzzled. He steps into the hall. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know about this dog, Tam - He notices two half-drunk beers. He wanders into the hall sees Ben's boots and most of Tamara's clothes, abandoned. unmistakable moans of lovemaking are coming from Tamara's room. He turns on his heels, pained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy strides back across the field, chucking the mushroom the mud on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 68aa POSY DRAWING 68aa GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 43A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postcard of Winnards Farm. The exterior is half-decorated Two cars parked - Tamara's and the yellow Porsche, which  looks more like a permanent fixture. The garden has been  cleared and dug, ready to plant.  Andy is stoking a bonfire. He is smouldering like the emb He gives the yellow Porsche an angry look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nicholas and Glen are both walking in the field. They pas each other, each managing a painful smile.  NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How goes the opus?  GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine Nicholas, just fine...  Their smiles fade. Nicholas descending into deep gloom, G into deep anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is mending the engine of her huge mower. Glen, now wearing a scarf, is sitting on the seat watching her work GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's his most obscure novel `The Well- Beloved'. Most people have never even heard of it. About this guy of twenty who falls in love with a beautiful young woman. Then when he's forty, he meets the woman's daughter and he falls in love with her. And finally, when he's sixty he meets the GRANDDAUGHTER - BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh he doesn't. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Falls in mystical love. Hardy was like that in his life, too. Even as he aged, he only had eyes for young women. Like, in one essential way he never grew up. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In his trousers. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was still at it in his eighties. You know? Snow on the rooftop but fire in the cellar... BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't it come for you Glen? The way you talk about it's so engaging. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but there's an academic style, you know? BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you writing for? Who's your ideal reader? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glen can't answer. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you wrote the way you spoke... it would make me want to read Hardy. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. If you wrote like you were talking to a friend... Pass me that thing. Glen passes it, looking at Beth as she tightens a bolt. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it now. Glen turns the key. The engine starts. Glen starts to dri the mower, delighted. Beth watches him, amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cosy dinner for all the writers - more ladies in their forties and fifties. Nicholas is topping up his glass. NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply pander to popular taste. CAITLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh your books are far more than that. NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just airport fodder... Glen at the foot of the table, finds this modesty rich. CAITLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your prose is so vivid. And Inchcombe - for all his flaws - is a man with total integrity. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you base him on, Nicholas? GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 46.   NICHOLAS (IGNORING GLEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My books don't say anything profound. I can't pretend to be an intellectual - not like Glen here, illuminating our ignorance with his critical glow - but I do love prose. And I think I can turn a reasonable story. Glen peers into the kitchen. Beth is serving desserts. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He goes to help her, leaving the ladies around Nicholas l cups around a teapot. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They need dusting with this. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to my room and I wrote for three hours. The time just vanished. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, that's brilliant. GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like a man who's just passed a gargantuan stool. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Super. Sprig of mint on the top. Glen returns to the dining room with two desserts. He lis to Nicholas as he serves them. NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The real secret of being a writer is learning how to lie. A frisson of shock goes round the lady writers. NICHOLAS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's what storytellers are. Thieves and liars... GLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he serves Nicholas) `The basis of all excellence is truth.' Samuel Johnson. Glen's intellect wins the day. Nicholas smarts. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 46A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room - her mother's - is empty except for a mattress the floor, clothes rail, designer bean bag and desk. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara is sitting at it, tapping away on her PC, almost pained with concentration. Ben is bored. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you done yet? TAMARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just starting something. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That poxy column? Can't it wait? TAMARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the column. Just stuff coming out. Don't want to stop it. BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it later. Play with me. Ben strums his guitar, determined to get her attention. BEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is such fun she's sexy And she lives on an old farm But something gnaws away at me It's causing me real harm. Tamara, what can you do with it? What can you do with her name? Its stands there lonely and rhymeless It's driving me nearly insane. Tamara the lovely, the ultimate, dazzling girl, Make me pasta carbonara, Cos I'm ravenous Tamara, Then shag me wearing your tiara... Tamara is delighted. She leaps on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy is planting a bed. Ben's boxer dog is digging up wor he's just done. Andy swears at him under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey - Andy? Andy looks up. Ben is at the bedroom window, naked. BEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you let my dog in? Thanks mate. Jody and Casey watch from behind the hedge as Andy angril goes to let the dog in. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 48.   CASEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must like kissing plastic. JODY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't love her. He's just on the rebound from losing Fran; numbing his pain with loads of empty, rampant sex. What he really needs... CASEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is a fifteen year old from Ewedown. JODY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Stranger things happen. He's only ten years older and that's nothing. If he met me, if he just met me... CASEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd be love, right? JODY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (SHE GRINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd settle for sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is feeding the hens. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coo-er... In your parents' bedroom? Still I suppose being an exhibitionist is part of his job - strutting about on stage. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't strut; he's a drummer. He sits on his arse. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good-looking, isn't he? Poppy You-Tubed him and we both got quite hot and bothered. Is that his car - the yellow Porsche? ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit brash, vrooming through the village... But fancy our Tamara bagging a bone fide rock star. She was such an ugly duckling. She must be thrilled to bits. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 48A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy can't listen to any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy peers through the door. Zoe is setting tables. He knocks. Zoe let's him in. ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not open for another hour. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy and Zoe are in the near-darkness, making love agains the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy is lying on one of the seats, his head on Zoe's lap. ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to move on soon, Andy. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way... GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 49.   ZOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know if I can stick a winter here. The way the light disappears; it's doing me in. I'm a blue sky girl. Got to have some warmth. Andy just looks up at her, smiling his understanding. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all need a bit of that, don't we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss is outside, sniffing round the front door. Sounds of end of an epic shag from the upstairs window. He sits, bo He hears the noise of crows in the field.  He is off like a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss is having the time of his life chasing the cows. Pen Upminister, an uppercrust landowner in a horrible coat is trying to catch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole herd is now on the rampage, Boss in pursuit, Pe bringing up the rear. Nicholas sees them heading straight his shed.  NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tamara is opening a Tiffany's box. There is a ring inside She looks at Ben, almost in disbelief. Boss can be heard, barks fading in the distance. TAMARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like? TAMARA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben... For which finger? BEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever one you like. That's a nice one. Why not put it on that? He's pointing to her ring finger. Tamara is moved. GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 49A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny Upminister has managed to get Boss on a bit of rope She is handing him over to Beth at the top of the field. PENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those girls could have aborted! GOLDENROD REVISIONS 20.10.09 50.   BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Penny. I'll sort him out. Nicholas is approaching. PENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It beats me why you people want to live in the country. You've got no sense of responsibility. BETH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our dog! NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Penny. How's tricks? Penny is suddenly all coy. PENNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - Nicholas... NICHOLAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking great. Terrific coat. PENNY
